snippet: A Russian plan to have international monitors take control of the Syrian government’s chemical weapons offered an exit strategy for President Obama, who had been reluctant to order a military strike.
abstract: Pres Obama tentatively embraces Russian diplomatic proposal to avert United States military strike on Syria by having international monitors take control of Syrian government’s chemical weapons; move adds new uncertainty to Obama’s push to win support among allies, the American public and members of Congress for an attack.

byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR, MICHAEL R. GORDON and STEVEN LEE MYERS
byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear reported from Washington, Michael R. Gordon from London, and Steven Lee Myers from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: A Russian plan to have international monitors take control of the Syrian government’s chemical weapons offered an exit strategy for President Obama, who had been reluctant to order a military strike.

headline.main: Obama Backs Idea for Syria to Cede Control of Arms
headline.print_headline: Obama Backs Idea for Syria to Cede Control of Arms

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
